body: Removed "bug" label since the issue here was in the test code.

run cpp tests
run java8 tests

How can I run checkstyle locally ?
mvn checkstyle:check -> fails
mvn validate -> does not run checkstyle

@merlimat  @sijie how can I add documentation for these new values ?
I am going to use such values in production tools I think it is better to create docs

> how can I add documentation for these new values ?

I would suggest adding a `managed-ledger` page for documenting all managed ledger related stuffs. `cookbooks` can be a good place for placing such page for right now. we can refactor when we have more documentations around "managed-ledger".

@sijie I am sorry but I am totally new to Pulsar and I don't feel I am able to write a brand new page about Managed Ledger.
I will take a look to "cookbook", thanks
@sijie is there any way to build a local preview of the website ?
@eolivelli you can checkout the README page - https://github.com/apache/pulsar/tree/master/site2

rerun java8 tests
rerun integration tests

@sijie I have tried to add the new page, under site2.
I have created a page similar to the other ones with name cookbooks-xxx but I can't see my page rendered.
Can you please help me ?
Thank you very much

> I have created a page similar to the other ones with name cookbooks-xxx but I can't see my page rendered.
> Can you please help me ?

1. did you add the page to the sidebar?
2. by default the doc is showing the stable version. you have to click `next` to see the latest version of the documentation.

Tried to run 100s of times in a loop within a Docker container on mac laptop and was not able to reproduce so far..
I think this might break the current stats generation for replication, since it's based on identifying replicators based on the producer name.

> I think this might break the current stats generation for replication, since it's based on identifying replicators based on the producer name.

Oh..is it? But I can see that 
[pulsar-replication-stats](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-broker/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/broker/service/persistent/PersistentTopic.java#L1232) uses `remote-cluster-name` for identifier. is that you were pointing or is there anything else as well?

I see.. good catch. we always see various types of issues with replicator and it would be better to keep local-cluster name into logs for the debugging. not sure, adding padding might be a good idea to avoid this breaking change here.?

We will investigate more detail.

@massakam @merlimat what will happen when certs and keys are rotating regularly ? earlier, on every new cnx if broker was reading certs then it can read new certs but now, do we have to restart broker?
@rdhabalia Good point. Maybe we could either cache for some configurable time (eg: 1hour) or monitor the file for changes

> @tuan6956 how many clusters do you have? Did you run this at the source cluster or the destination cluster?

i have 3 cluster, and i ran at this at the source and the destination cluster
+1 to @rdhabalia 's comment. I think broker-shaded was introduced for addressing some requirements from slack users. it is not like the other shaded modules I removed in #3559

I want to subscribe to a topic(channel) from the browser(consumer), the server side(backend) as the producer. 

So that I can replace [Pusher](https://pusher.com/) or [Pubnub](https://www.pubnub.com/) with the pulsar. 

Not server to server, but server to the browser.
@lanlin you can check websocket proxy in pulsar. http://pulsar.apache.org/docs/en/client-libraries-websocket.html#docsNav
@sijie Ok, added the PersistentTopicsTest. There are a couple more tests to go, but other than that, this PR should be getting close.
@sijie @merlimat Are you already working on system topic now? I want to add dispatch rate limitation for a topic, it seems depends on system topic.

@lanlin there is a token-based authentication mechanism introduced in 2.3.0. You can checkout the details here : http://pulsar.apache.org/docs/en/next/security-token-admin/

2.3.0 will be released in 1 week or so.

> instead of using python library to write customized parsing logic, have you considered using maven plugin to extract the version?

There are a couple of issues there: 
 * Maven can take long time to get started
 * The process will output all the maven logs and we'd have to manually parse out all these lines

I wouldn't say that this is customized parsing logic, since we're just parsing the XML and picking the version element there.

> Maybe we could either cache for some configurable time (eg: 1hour) or monitor the file for changes

Yes, we can fix it with that alternative. I will make the change to fix it. 👍

https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/3568/files - this PR should do what
Rajan suggested.

rerun cpp tests
rerun java8 tests

@david-streamlio after some thinking bundling multiple sources or sinks in NARs is problematic for us to support.  Our current reasoning for using the NAR format for connectors is so that users don't have to 1) upload anything (for built-in connectors) and 2) so that the user don't have to specify a classpath.  If we were to bundle multiple sources or sinks in a single NAR, the user has to now specify a classpath or some identifier which adds not only complexity to our code but as well as user experience.  

Bundling multiple sources and sinks into a NAR makes sense for built-in connectors, but currently we also allow users to submit NARs from the CLI for source and sinks. Like I mentioned before, having to support submitting NARs with multiple sources and sinks adds a lot more additional complexity in the code as we must also support submitting NARs with single sources and sinks. We will have to support NARs of two different formats. User's will also have to uploaded a larger package than needed as the NAR with contain code and dependencies for other sources an sinks.

So, after poking around for far too long on this, this works out of the box. Nothing needs to change on the client side (maybe C++ client, I dunno were it gets its certs).

For future reference, when you generate a cert with let's encrypt certbot, you only need to use fullchain.pem and privkey.pem. Privkey needs to be converted to pk8,
```
openssl pkcs8 -topk8 -inform PEM -outform PEM -in privkey.pem -out privkey.pk8.pem -nocrypt
```

Then the proxy should be configured only setting the cert and privkey. trusted certs can be left empty.
```
tlsCertificateFilePath=/home/ivan/pulsar/checkouts/letsencrypt/fullchain.pem
tlsKeyFilePath=/home/ivan/pulsar/checkouts/letsencrypt/privkey.pk8.pem
tlsTrustCertsFilePath=
```
